Hi all, in case anyone would like to read entire the "Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time" book by Jeff Sutherland but don't want to buy the book on Amazon, you can borrow it off your local library using Libby or Overdrive for free! Here are easy 4 steps on how to do so:

1.	Register for a Boston Public Library eCard - <https://www.bpl.org/ecard/>. It’s free to anyone with an address in MA.
2.	Sign up for an Overdrive account here –  <https://www.overdrive.com/media/1678411/scrum> OR download the Libby app on iOS /Android - <https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/libby-by-overdrive/id1076402606?mt=8>.
3.	Link your Libby/Overdrive account to your Boston Public Library eCard, and now you can borrow ebooks and audiobooks for free! As mentioned above, the Scrum book by Jeff Sutherland is available at BPL. The audiobook is narrated by JJ Sutherland and I quite like it.
4.	If you want to view the book on your laptop, on the app Libby on your phone, go to the ebook you’ve borrowed on your shelf, and click “Send to Kindle”. Then, download the Kindle for PC/Mac program, log in, and you should be all set!

If anyone has any questions do let me know! I’m a big fan of Libby/Overdrive and am happy to troubleshoot.

# This file seeks to identify all expenditure in food and beverage above 100 dollars by the US House of Representatives
This new program looks at gasoline expenditures over 100 dollars. The goal is to see if certain offices are paying significantly more for gas expenses as a proxy for positive constituent service.

This CSV file contains congressional expenditures whose purposes included the phrase "carpet" and that exceeded $500 in the first quarter of 2017. There are 26 such transactions, most of which were made by either the Chief Administrative Officer of the House or by the Furnishings Office.
This subset of data represents rows where someone has made payment to policy advisor for more than $10,000. Turned out that very few members did aside from the committee on budget.

Each quarter, we budget about $20 million for our congressional chiefs of staff. If you are looking for a chief of staff role in the future, the economic prospects look like they can vary by quite a wide margin. 105 amounts paid were for $935 in the quarter. I would hope that these are biweekly paychecks, but this would seem to hover right around the poverty line. On the other hand, 66 people were paid $41,167 for the quarter which would lend itself to a nice salary. Also, if you are looking for a chief of staff position, it would appear that Nancy Pelosi would be the place to start -- she had twice the payments compared to the speaker of the house, Paul Ryan! (Although more analysis can be done to see if these may be due to accounting rather than personnel differences).

This output file contains expenditures on postage that exceeded $100. These 175 rows constituted less than 6% of the 3064 total postage-related transactions but accounted for over 40% of the total dollar amount spent in this category. Private companies like Fedex and UPS are the most common recipients in this file rather than the government-run USPS, which could indicate a general preference for private companies and/or that their services tend to be more expensive.

This file contains a subset of payees, specifically Deer Park. They have on an average spent USD 1367 between 2016-2017 on water consumption, which is relatively less than the average spending on water when all payments are considered.

Gini Table 1

The U.S. Tax Cut and Jobs Act of 2017 created the Opportunity Zone Program to provide incentives for investment in low income communities throughout the country. An Opportunity Zone is a designated geographic area, in which individuals can gain favorable tax treatment on their capital gains, by investing those funds (through a privately-created Opportunity Fund) into economic activities in the area. The U.S. Treasury has designated 138 tracts in 79 Massachusetts communities as Opportunity Zones. The Opportunity Zone program presents an opportunity for private, tax-advantaged investment into areas of economic need, benefiting both residents living in the zones and private investors. Governor Charlie Baker announced the designations on May 18, 2018.

Some of the Massachusetts opportunity zones certified by the U.S. Department of the Treasury have left locals scratching their heads over why an incentive is needed to build. While low-income parts of Fall River, Springfield and New Bedford made the cut, so did neighborhoods in places like the tourist-heavy Provincetown as well as Alewife in West Cambridge, which developers are already building up as a life science relief valve to Kendall Square.

So I just reviewed the requirements and the only thing I could find that we *didn’t* do was make a README file for each graphic that we put on our site.

From Dhrumil:
Your Dataset

We’re not going to have a proper “back end” server that pulls from a database and serves up an API. Rather, you will find a dataset and place it in a folder within your repository.

For each dataset you should have:

a copy of the original data in the format you got it in
a README.md or README.txt file with a link to the original data source and an explanation about how you transformed the original data into the final format you needed. If you’ve done the transformation using a python script, just uplaod that script (no need to document). If you used some other means, please document your data transformation process in the README file. It should be a step by step explanation, not just one pithy sentence like “I transformed the data with excel”.
a copy of the final data which will be consumed by the visualization
Remember, sometimes you might be able to tell a better story by filtering the data down to an interesting subset rather than visualizing all of it.

Hey <#CF6DAAQ2D|b1_econ_policy>, I have two ideas that I think might be worthwhile for my contribution to our project:

My *first idea* involves using real-time economic data from the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA), Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the U.S. Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve in order to provide visitors to our site with a real time update on the state of the U.S. economy as indicators are updated. In order to make it as seamless as possible, I would like to build an API to draw this data in as it's released from government agencies.

Examples of where to find the data might be:
<https://fred.stlouisfed.org/tags/series?t=nipa>,
<https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/Pages/index.aspx>,
<https://www.bea.gov/data/gdp/gross-domestic-product>,
<https://www.bls.gov/bls/unemployment.htm>

And the visualization could look similar to the FT's monitor on their website: <https://ig.ft.com/sites/numbers/economies/us>

My *second idea* is similar, but involves visualizing equities using real-time stock data from <http://yahoo.finance.com|yahoo.finance.com> to build a dataset of equities to model stock performance in real time.

Let me know what you guys think and looking forward to chatting with you all tomorrow in class!

It has been very challenging to work in the group within a scrum mindset. We often see ourselves reproducing functions and defining work flow as in the waterfall model, just by pure habit. On the other hand, thanks to Scrum, we have perceived more clarity in the details of the necessary processes to reach the goals defined by user stories. This clarity, in addition to ensuring our focus on the scope of the work, also gives us more confidence about the effort that will be required to undertake each of the tasks in the TODO list.
Just wondering if other classmates are having the same experiences.

Reading through Sutherland's book on why he founded Scrum was interesting to me. It brought me back to my days as a management consultant. In one of our projects, we had too many people involved with no clear, quick way to keep track of the deliverables. One of the consultants introduced SCRUM to the leadership team, including only the top 7 people leading each team to provide very quick headlines on their progress and the roadblocks.

Ultimately, SCRUM didn't hold up to our expectations. As <@UF19DNZ5E> mentioned, it is difficult to implement SCRUM on monumental size projects. In total, we had over 150 people working on the project, and to narrow it down to just 7 people for frequent, daily meetings meant that these 7 people spent their entire days obtaining updates from their staff, however small. They did not trust leaders from other teams, hence the stand-up meetings simply became somewhat of a pissing contest. Saying nothing would have been terribly embarrassing and nobody wants to talk about their roadblocks. This was in Southeast Asia, where "saving one's face" is commonly important.

As mentioned by my other classmates, I wonder if SCRUM has a place in large scale projects, and in areas where cultures where trust is not the norm. I'm only halfway through the book and am still reading up more material, so I hope I will be convinced otherwise by the end of this class!

Really enjoyed this set of readings. Two strains of thought came to mind, both related to personal career experiences. First off, these readings have continually reinforced how my first job at IBM in IT project management was largely learning an obsolete craft. For two years, we were ingrained to employ the waterfall method and consistently valued documentation and project tracking over actually getting the software done right by creating user value. We slowly started to do some things to shift towards agile lite like deploying automated testing and breaking the massive phased projects into smaller chunks that were somewhat "Sprint" like. Still, a valuable experience to learn the pitfalls of a failed approach (which were demonstrated by our constant project delays and client tension. Second, the readings made me think about my own effort this summer in Chicago to promote a "US Digital Service Model" for Chicago's City Government. Serving as an intern in the Mayor's Office, we were each tasked with proposing a New Idea as part of annual competition. I had read about the US Digital Service Model and a similar version at the city level in Austin, TX and decided to proposed replicating it Chicago. It was interesting how the turf war nature of Chicago's city government immediately disliked the idea of IT folks coming in and messing with traditional lines of authority. By the end of the summer, I was able to make some progress in encouraging the idea, but it demonstrated the difficulty in pitching "good ideas" with proven results, especially when they cause disruption in the status quo.
Edited for clarity.

I wonder how much Agile and Scrum have been explored in other sectors and what the results have been. A good example is that of R&D grants. Granting agencies like NSF or DoE traditionally grant resources to R&D projects based on a waterfall approach. The R&D process is one of information discovery, meaning that at the onset of a project, the outcomes could be predicted but not guaranteed. On top of that, an R&D project can reveal new information that is not known before the grant was awarded but that merits pursuing new and different activities. Researchers and granting agencies could benefit highly from adopting an agile framework in which grants are approved based on scientific merit of a team and the general ideas they want to pursue. Progress can be reviewed in sprints and rather than having a complete project described at the onset, the activities could flow with the newly acquired information to areas that show higher promise for breakthrough or innovation.

I was particularly moved by The Atlantic article about <http://Healthcare.gov|Healthcare.gov>. At the risk of sounding too idealistic/naïve (which Sam appropriately addresses above), I was pretty excited to think about this team of coders tackling such a massive and important system and ultimately being able to cut the cost of building the system by $256 million and the cost of annual maintenance by $69 million. I wish I could understand coding better just so I can get a more technical understanding of their approach. How did this team know where to even begin when they opened the login page and identified glitches?
The part about the team having to wait to get a security review on AWS really resonated with me as someone who worked in federal contracting before coming to HKS. Deadlines often get pushed further and further into the future for project components that in theory shouldn’t be a source of stress, which can be frustrating. This relates to a topic that I would love to have the speakers’ take on: there seems to be so many “blockers” to implementing significant change in government systems- from budgeting to deep-seated silos to outdated procurement to overall skepticism. What would the speakers say are major barriers to applying scrum in the public sector that one wouldn’t typically see in the private sector, and how do they envision overcoming them using Scrum techniques? In the second Scrum reading, one of the barriers, skepticism, was raised, but the solution was glossed over. I imagine this is a major issue in the public sector, but also an inconsistent one. I wonder if the speakers have any experience/successes with overcoming it that they could share.

I agree with many of the questions raised, here are a few of my thoughts from the readings:
- I’d love to learn about what agile looks like in non-tech environments or with teams that aren’t creating a software product. Echoing Danny’s question, I’m looking forward to hearing from our speakers about how to successfully implement agile and scrum in the context of a more hierarchical/traditional organization.
- In “Elements of Scrum”, I loved learning about determining the relative amount of work each task will require. It seems like a way of allocating time and effort that is so intuitive, I might apply it to my own to do lists.
- In reading the <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> articles, one mentioned the failure of opening the website to everyone at once instead of starting with a small circle to get feedback, iterate, and expand to more people over time. While starting small and iterating seems to be the way to get a good working product, in the context of a government service, how do you decide who gets first access in an equitable manner? Is it unfair to offer it to some, but not others? Alternatively, this may be irrelevant if we set up the roll out to be transparent about who will get access and when.

Many policymakers are painfully unaware of how data can be used to advance their policy goals in a more targeted way to better serve constituents. Even slow and cumbersome systems like at the FBI can prevent organizational missions from being completed successfully. In my personal experience, government technology systems lag behind those of private firms, and for some obvious reasons (like funding). But if improving technology improves the functionality of government, then technology enhancements should be a top priority for governments.

A question to our guest speakers: what are the main barriers to productivity or effectiveness in your experience in government? What are some specific ways we can apply the agile/scrum mindset to overcome obstacles to flow in our teams? And, given that not everyone on a team will have experience working in scrum, what methods should we use to change the mindset of our teams? I don’t want to rely too much on training, but at the same time, these processes only work if everyone buys in. So, especially if we are not the team manager, how do we promote buy in and collaboration around this approach?

It also seems like there are tradeoffs between getting work done as quickly as possible and doing it right, even if it takes slightly longer. It makes sense that most teams have areas where efficiency can be improved, but in some cases the teams are working as fast as can be reasonably expected. As a manager, what tools can be used to identify the point at which efficiencies are being maximized, without crossing over into the space where errors are being made?

Scrum/Agile is definitely a thought provoking approach to team management.  I worry a bit that there may be a false dichotomy between a more agile approach and a waterfall method.  Here are a few of the concerns I came up with:
-Scalability.  Its not clear to me how scrums would work on monumental size projects.  Communication between hierarchical or peer scrums is not facilitated.  This could result in teams independently "re-inventing the wheel" to solve the same or similar problems.  Additionally, Scrum's heavy reliance on trust would make it very hard to incorporate into big organizations.  Similarly, self organizing teams seems unlikely in some of these institutions.
-Story choice aggregation.  The increasingly short nature of sprints makes the focus more and more on small user choices.  For instance, Facebook programmers might be looking at a user story in which the user desires some convenience at a small cost of privacy.  This story may be perfectly fine in the individual case, but as the same choice is repeated you can end up in a place you never expected.
-Similarly, some choices and priorities are inherently more likely to "win" out over time.  For instance, a story about user convenience is likely relatively straightforward and easily quantifiable (some period of time saved).  A story about privacy is likely to be much more convoluted and more difficult to break into bite sized pieces.  Thus by the Scrum methodology, the convenience story is likely to continuously rise to the top of the list while privacy remains at the bottom as a bigger, more nebulous story.  This is true of other concepts such as autonomy (freedom) vs safety or security.
-Organized labor.  I've been trying to conceptualize what a Scrum environment would look like in an industry with strong unions.  Haven't come up with anything yet.

This isn't intended to be overly negative towards the Agile process, it has many advantages.  Is there a way to combine the advantages of a Scrum-like approach with those from Waterfall planning?

In thinking about the readings this weekend, something that struck me is that the issue of making change in government is something that is widespread and not limited to the tech sphere. Some of this likely has to do with the rigid structure in which government departments operate, which makes me wonder: how can we change government as a whole to keep up with the changing demands of the 21st century?

In reading the articles about <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> from Time, The Atlantic, et al, I was struck by what seemed to me like a mismatch between one of the central principles of agile—customer collaboration—and the way the articles discuss the coders as sort of distant, superhuman, all-powerful code magicians (e.g. the Time article calls them “tech wizards” and alludes to Gabriel Burt’s background in rocket science). That isn’t to say that the folks who got <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> working weren’t very smart or talented, but it seems like the agile ideal would be to have them integrated more smoothly into the government’s infrastructure, able to collaborate with non-coder colleagues on a day-to-day basis. Granted, a lot of the mystique here might be media-created and not reflective of the on-the-ground experience of government employees who worked with the coders, but it still seems like scrum has a bit of an image problem. I wonder what teams using scrum methods can do to overcome programming's mystique and appear more approachable for non-coder stakeholders, since it won’t do much good for coders to want to collaborate if the non-coders are hesitant to do so.

Some stories in the reading were very interesting.  Other digital HKS courses, such as Product Management, Digital Government, and Future Issues in Cyber-Security Policy also mentioned about differences between waterfall and agile. It is very interesting to find that the FBI could have linked information about 9/11 in advance if there was a better computer system. Similarly, projects that failed due to waterfall were mentioned in various ways. (f-35 fighter jet development failure) But I wonder how a specific case was specifically planned based on waterfall and what the plan was looked like. And it would be interesting if there's an analysis about how such case could be designed in an agile format.

The reading started with the traditional waterfall method that operates project step by step, and makes sure each step works well and led to the result. Whereas the Scrum is taking the working process as a holistic process. Question: the efficiency about scrum. Because of its working principal, Scrum is frequently deliver with small changes, but how could these indirect mix-up steps can help clients who don’t really have professional skills understand its value when it’s on early stages.

Also found the readings very enjoyable. I have 3 questions in mind. 1) Flexible processes sound good but where does the overall budgeting comes in? Particularly for projects such as government ones that require annual budgeting, how does the method estimate long-term budget beyond identified sprint work?  2) How do teams balance releasing minimal viable products and limiting vulnerability against cyber security threats etc? Again, I am curious about government projects that require extra caution and face critical scrutiny (and where people love "control and predictability" and less tolerant about failures). 3) Scrum members have total authority over how the work gets done and seem to have lots of discretion. How does the team ensure continuity if  a team member left unexpectedly, given that there is no detailed documentation?

My initial thoughts after the readings are basically centered around agile vs waterfall and if agile is adoptable in non-tech environments. In my experience, it is not completely useless to have pre-defined goals, expectations and deadlines. I am curious to hear how agile methodologies have been received and adopted in traditionally bureaucratic spaces and how fast (or not?) it was to get people efficiently working with them.

The Wired article on the USDS mentions uncertainty about the future of the agency a few times. Particularly because this article was written in the summer of 2016 (prior to the US presidential election), I was curious how the Trump administration had impacted the USDS. Seems that the USDS is still mostly chugging along (<https://www.wired.com/story/obamas-us-digital-service-survives-trumpquietly/>), although they frame their work differently given the change in political priorities and are having a more difficult time recruiting. However, this really highlights for me the additional challenges of making change of this kind in government, where beyond the usual culture struggles there is a broader layer of political ideology that could be very complex to navigate. Curious to see what our speakers have to say about this!

I'm still reflecting on the Scrum readings, but a few initial thoughts and questions:
-One aspect I feel like most of the readings glossed over was how the "gathering requirements" step is much faster or more efficient using Agile methodologies or Scrums.  Wouldn't you still need to do the legwork of understanding basic requirements and creating User Stories?  How long does this take?  What makes it fundamentally faster than the same step in the Waterfall?  My understanding is that it leads to efficiencies down the line as you only prioritize what is truly needed, but in order to do that, don't you still need to build this basic foundation of requirements?
-I'm curious about how the contract negotiation and expectation setting works using this model.  I thought the readings made great points about the added bureaucracy, difficulty in sticking to predetermined milestones, and frequent cost overruns using the Waterfall method.  But it also highlighted the skepticism that stakeholders may have towards the limited information an agile team would be able to provide at the offset of a project.  It looks like most agile teams are able to build trust with stakeholders over time through constant interaction and early delivery of working products, but how do they get over the first hurdle?  How have these teams been able to avoid the pitfalls of the Waterfall approach and structure more efficient contracts while also managing  their stakeholders' expectations?
-Echoing some of the sentiments brought up in class, even after the readings I have a keen sense that using Scrum teams must be predicated on having a really strong and motivated team.  Based on my own experience working across a couple of different sectors, I really have a hard time visualizing this working in many non-tech environments.  I would be really curious to hear successful cases of where this has worked beyond technology development
-As a bit of an aside, I was a bit surprised by the harsh treatment "Scrum: The Art of Doing Work in Half the Time" gave to Gantt Charts.  While it's likely not the best way to plan projects, I've seen them used very successfully in general project planning (though I may be biased given my background--in my former life as a consultant and when working with non-profits, setting clear project plans, deadlines, and expectations were essential).  This relates to my previous point in that I'm still a bit skeptical of how well this approach works in other contexts

One question I have after doing the readings is: “how can different scrum teams collaborate?” And, relatedly, “how do you adapt scrum when you fail to meet the two pizza rule?”

In our class (section b), we have groups that are 4 people and an overall group with 16 people. We are using scrum for both groups, but one group is smaller than recommended and one is larger - in our small group, we haven’t designated a project owner, scrum master, etc. which seems appropriate for the timeframe, but have other groups tried to put in additional structures? In the overall class, we will still have standup with all 16 people, but would it make more sense to designate one person per group to talk about how the class is working for that group’s learning goals? Is there a way that scrum structures can cascade upwards easily?

Alternatively, or in addition, should there be a way in which scrum groups dialogue about what is working or share their learnings with the greater team. I shared this in the general thread, but I'll share with the team as well. I created a google doc as a glossary of all the command terms across languages because I was having a difficult time recalling them in class or during the homework. Feel free to use it and add to it:

As a disaster response agency, I want to understand the connection between climate change and increased frequency of natural disasters so that my agency can create long term plans and budget estimates.

As a company or land developer, I want to be able to see where occurrences of disasters are most frequent so that I can make business decisions with the best information available to me.

As a climate resilience expert, I want to see which regions experience the greatest human loss from each kind of disaster so that I can better target programs and policies to reduce suffering and help communities bounce back from disaster.

As a philanthropist, I want to know where and how often the biggest disasters occur in terms of both human economic loss so that I can prioritize my charitable work and generate the biggest positive impact.

As someone who is skeptical about climate change, I want to see for myself whether or not more natural disasters are occurring over time and whether or not they are increasing in intensity/impact so that I can determine how much I will support efforts to prevent future impacts.

As a federal policy maker I want global benchmarks on disaster impact and disaster response / prevention funding to understand whether the U.S. is underperforming relative to peer countries

As a federal policy maker I want information on historic trends to understand whether disasters are becoming more frequent and/or severe

As a federal policy maker I want information on relative frequency and impact of different types of disasters to appropriately allocate response and prevention funding

As Dima I want to learn how to visualize time series and maps to effectively present social science data in my work and studies

As a climate change activist I want a website with a clear and coherent storyline that addresses the link between climate change and disasters
I mostly focused on one user persona with several needs (seems plausible that one user can have several needs)

My Approach has been topic agnostic, since Jon has done such a terrific job with by looking at User Stories from our topic.

User Stories

1.	As Ruha I want to be able to develop a website with hyperlinks to outside resources and embedded visualizations so that a visitor can get a comprehensive picture of the selected topic.

2.	As a student of DPI 691M, I want to be able to learn from my fellow classmates so that I can internalize the skills being taught in class.

3.	As a news-junkie, I want to visit a website on Topic X which is updated and relevant so that I can be informed with the latest data and trends.

4.	As a Harvard Professor, I want A2’s project to be based on impartial data and objectively analysed so that the public website shows critical, unbiased thinking of policy students.

5.	As a person interested in Topic X, I want original interpretation and refreshing insights, not mere repetition, so that I gain a different perspective on Topic X.

I am a policy maker who wants to understand whether investment in climate change mitigation will help reduce the effects of natural disasters so that I can make informed decisions around appropriations

I am a resident concerned about how climate change affects natural disasters so that I can better understand the risk to my home.

I am a meteorologist interested in understanding the increased risk of natural disasters as a result of climate change so that I can better prepare my constituents/viewers for future climate events.

I am a business owner looking for information about extreme weather events so that I can make an informed decision about investing in weather preparedness.

I am a climate change skeptic looking for a website with a weak narrative or poor data analysis so that I can easily poke holes in its conclusions. (Anti-user story)

Here are some questions to keep in mind when searching for data:
* How have frequency or extent of fires changed?
* How has drought changed?
* How has sea level and flooding changed? How has coastal development changed?
* How have landslides gotten more frequent?
* How are cities dealing with climate-related hazards?
* How much has the state spent on flooding? Has this changed over time? On fire over time?  What about specific cities?

Hi all, so my initial idea was that we could show how the recent election in Brazil changed the climate policy outlook in the country. I thought it would be interesting to visualize Brazil’s climate goals (from their INDC) and show how Bolsonaro’s policies compare. We could break this down by sector and potentially showing how this could affect Amazon forest cover by using Google Earth Engine (which uses Javascript to work with satellite imagery).

Since talking to the team, it seems like it may be better to do something more centered on climate change impacts on the city. We could take a few different case studies (based on what data is available) and try to visualize current and future impacts of climate change. If possible, I would like to try my hand at Google Earth Engine through this project (one of my learning goals), but I think this software could have various applications to a potential project including showing drought, forest cover, and other landscape-level changes.

*Here is what I wrote out about the first idea that I think we will not use*:
* Show how Bolsonaro’s policies could impact the Amazon rainforest
* How that could relate to climate change
* How that could relate to Brazil’s NDC and climate goals (I wrote a memo on Brazil’s NDC and climate goals before Bolsonaro was elected)

Things we need:
* Understanding of previous policy (have this)
